Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Phylogeographic analysis of introgressive gene flow among nuclear loci functionally linked to the mitochondrion
Award.AbstractNarration:
Genetic studies across species frequently uncover conflicting patterns between the nuclear and organellar (including mitochondria) genomes. Contrasting patterns of genomic divergence can potentially be explained by differences related to inheritance, gene flow, and mutation rate, but it is unknown how co-evolutionary interactions between these genomes influence genetic divergence. Using Dusky Salamanders and revolutionary DNA sequencing technologies, evolutionary patterns of divergence will be compared between the nuclear and mitochondrial genomes, with a focus on nuclear genes that function within the mitochondrion. Dusky salamanders are an excellent system for this project because they are regionally diverse in eastern North America and have demonstrated gene flow across species boundaries. These criteria, and the growing genetic resources available for salamanders, make them an excellent system to test for conflicting evolutionary patterns between nuclear and nuclear-encoded mitochondrial genes.

This research will contribute toward graduate student training in the use of rapidly changing and advancing genetic technologies and help preparations for an academic career through peer-reviewed research and undergraduate mentorship. Results from this study will provide new insights into how researchers should use genomic data to reconstruct the Tree of Life, and will contribute to an understanding of the processes that influence genetic divergence and speciation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Historically, mitochondrial genetic markers have been an important asset contributing to our knowledge of the shared evolutionary relationships among different eukaryotic taxa across the tree of life. The tendency for mitochondrial markers to introgress or transfer between species, however, challenges the utility of such markers for recovering species level phylogenetic relationships among taxa and complicates our understanding of the genetic boundaries distinguishing species.

In this project we examined concordance between evolutionary patterns generated using nuclear markers and mitochondrial markers in different taxa with evidence of historical mitochondrial introgression. We also utilized genetic information from nuclear encoded mitochondrial markers, which function or interact with mitochondrial processes such as cellular respiration and signaling. We discovered that there is strong discordance between mitochondrial and nuclear genetic patterns whether or not nuclear loci had a mitochondrial function. Furthermore, results suggest mitochondrial patterns inadequately characterize the complex evolutionary history present in the nuclear history of a species. This research reinforces the need for multi-locus nuclear data in addressing the systematic and population genetic relationships across diverse taxa.

Funding provided for this project supported the dissertation of a graduate student, who directly mentored four undergraduates in molecular laboratory and bioinformatic research. All of these mentees are members of underrepresented groups in science, are pursuing graduate school or similar professional careers, and one student went on to earn a competitive departmental award for their undergraduate research while participating on this project.
